title: Bargain Hunt presenter Tim Wonnacott criticised over payment for Shaun the Sheep charity auction
text:
Bargain Hunt presenter Tim Wonnacott criticised over payment for Shaun the Sheep charity auction Bargain Hunt presenter Tim Wonnacott criticised over payment for Shaun the Sheep charity auction 
Press Association 2014 / / National Entertainment News Share 
Bargain Hunt’s Tim Wonnacott has been criticised over money he will earn for a charity auction benefiting sick children around the country. 
Earlier this month, it was reported that the 62-year-old had been suspended by the BBC, pending inquiries into an alleged disagreement with producers. Tim Wonnacott (Yui Mok/PA) 
Now the under-fire presenter is due to be the celebrity auctioneer for 120 sculptures of Shaun the Sheep when the flock go under the hammer on Thursday October 8 at The Mall, Cribbs Causeway. 
Five feet high replicas of Aardman Animation’s famous sheep were placed around London and Bristol a couple of months ago; there were 50 in the capital during spring, while 70 decorated the streets of Bristol, Aardman’s base, in the summer. 
The Gromit Unleashed auction, which took place in 2013 with Mr Wonnacott hosting, brought in £2.35 million for those in need. Shaun the Sheep sculptures (Lauren Hurley/PA Wire/Press Association Images) 
Alongside other artists appearing, the popular BBC star will be paid for his role in the project. 
Following criticism from some, who say they would have offered their services for free, Bargain Hunt’s Tim defended his position to the Bristol Post. Promoted stories 
“The arrangements I have with the charity are confidential and I don’t really want to get into that,” he said. 
“I absolutely believe in this affair. It’s been an extraordinary experience and a wonderful way of raising money for the charity, and for me it’s something that is important. 
“It is an important part of my calendar, and I’m delighted to have been asked to take part.” 
Money raised from sales of the London sculptures will go to the Wallace & Gromit Children’s Charity, which supports children in hospitals across the country. (David Parry/PA Archive/PA Images) 
Funds from the Bristol sculptures will go to The Grand Appeal, the charity supporting Bristol Children’s Hospital and St Michael’s Hospital, also in Bristol. 
Nicola Masters, director of the Grand Appeal charity, said: “Tim has been a long-standing supporter of The Grand Appeal and there is a commercial arrangement between us. 
“This is in order to make sure that we have the very best auctioneer, with the expert knowledge to help us maximise funds for the Grand Appeal, the Bristol Children’s Hospital charity.” 
She added all of the auction proceeds will benefit sick children. “We do have a commercial arrangement with Tim, but it is not on commission and it is not going to come from the proceeds of the auction which will be entirely in support of the Grand Appeal and Wallace and Gromit charity.” 
Auctioneer Evan Mcpherson, who owns East Bristol Auctions, said he said he expects the sculptures to fetch at least £3.5 million to £4 million in total. (Ben Birchall/PA Archive/PA Images) 
In reference to the star’s fee, Evan said: “He is a TV personality and has a presence, so you can see why he’s getting paid. Share article 
“But I know one of my auctioneers who would do it for nothing because he loves the Shauns and wants to do something for charity.” Promoted Stories
